title: Support VMRC
author: damageboy
body_snippet:
VMWare provides a client called vmrc that enables to view remote VM *console* widows.
Support in mRemoteNG would be great!

comments.snippet: This would complete mRemoteNG for me :)
comments.author: bignick8t3

comments.author: sparerd

comments.snippet:
The web console can sometimes be a bit hit and miss with keyboard mappings so the installed console is what I use.

Looking at the following it would appear that VMRC can be automated:
https://communities.vmware.com/thread/508020

In the last post is the following:

VMware-VMRC-10.0.2-7096020.exe /V /Qn EULAS_AGREED=1 AUTOSOFTWAREUPDATE=0 ATACOLLECTION=0 /L "%USERPROFILE%\Desktop\vmrc.log"
comments.author: bignick8t3

comments.snippet:
Good to know about the web console.

The link you provided seems to be talking about automating the msi installer for VMRC, rather than automating VMRC itself.

I haven't used VMRC myself - is it a little bit like vSphere for managing VMs?
comments.author: sparerd

comments.snippet:
VMRC is VMware remote console, so you could hit a remote vm console for a variety of cases which rdp doesn't cover like:
* booting into a rescue env. Inside the VM (no networking)
* Linux console
* remote  installation
comments.author: damageboy

comments.snippet:
As ESXi has primarily gone web based if you launch the console via VMRC from the web GUI it opens a link that VMRC opens so I guess that's what mRemoteNG would need to know when saving a connection as such?

I'll see if I can get en example link that is used when you launch the console.
comments.author: bignick8t3

comments.snippet:
So this appears to be the best method:

`"C:\Program Files (x86)\VMware\VMware Remote Console\vmrc.exeΓÇ¥ -H [esxi ip or hostname] -U [user] -P [password] -M [VM ID]"`

This will launch VMRC and give you access to the console of specified VM.

VM ID's can be obtained from the address bar of the ESXi gui when you select a VM or by running the following from the ESXi CLI.

`vim-cmd vmsvc/getallvms`

This method worked for me using ESXi standalone, there are other methods if using vCentre...
